content.raw:
Gazebo loads embedded textures as long as Gazebo can find the texture. For example, take a look at the `nist_maze_wall_120` model. The Collada file contains embedded textures, and Gazebo loads them.

I think the problem is that the Collada files for the Atlas robot are correct only for ROS, and not for Gazebo. By that I mean, we are not properly telling Gazebo where to look for textures.

You have gotten around this by telling Gazebo via material scripts in SDF. The longer term solution will be to fix the Atlas package.

Long story short: Atlas robot model is probably the culprit.
content.html:
Gazebo loads embedded textures as long as Gazebo can find the texture. For example, take a look at the nist_maze_wall_120 model. The Collada file contains embedded textures, and Gazebo loads them.

I think the problem is that the Collada files for the Atlas robot are correct only for ROS, and not for Gazebo. By that I mean, we are not properly telling Gazebo where to look for textures.

You have gotten around this by telling Gazebo via material scripts in SDF. The longer term solution will be to fix the Atlas package.

Long story short: Atlas robot model is probably the culprit.

content.raw:
Textures also don't load for the new gazebo_models models like the ranger (only one i tested but I'm guessing it's the same for the other). Maybe the problem/difference is that ROS uses the .dae file's location while Gazebo uses some Gazebo dir or root?

Regarding the missing head color I guess it's due to the urdf->sdf conversion bug that dropped the material tag which already got fixed in some branch though I think (can't find the ticket right now).

I just noticed that ``nist_mase_wall_120`` uses just the filename instead of relative path to the materials/textures/ folder ... maybe that's what Gazebo is using while ros relies on a relative path?

Edit: hmmm, nope, removing the relative filepath in the .dae files and leaving just the texture name only breaks it in rviz but doesn't make it work in gazebo. Using an absolute filepath doesn't seem to work either, so the issue is something else I guess.

Edit2: what's also interesting is that Meshlab loads textures correctly for the NIST wall but not for the objects that also fail for Gazebo. So the FBX collada exporter (used for Atlas) and OpenCOLLADA exporter (used for polaris) seem to be doing something different than Blender's and SketchUp's exporters that rviz is able to handle but other programs including gazebo aren't.
content.html:
Textures also don't load for the new gazebo_models models like the ranger (only one i tested but I'm guessing it's the same for the other). Maybe the problem/difference is that ROS uses the .dae file's location while Gazebo uses some Gazebo dir or root?

Regarding the missing head color I guess it's due to the urdf->sdf conversion bug that dropped the material tag which already got fixed in some branch though I think (can't find the ticket right now).

I just noticed that nist_mase_wall_120 uses just the filename instead of relative path to the materials/textures/ folder ... maybe that's what Gazebo is using while ros relies on a relative path?

Edit: hmmm, nope, removing the relative filepath in the .dae files and leaving just the texture name only breaks it in rviz but doesn't make it work in gazebo. Using an absolute filepath doesn't seem to work either, so the issue is something else I guess.

Edit2: what's also interesting is that Meshlab loads textures correctly for the NIST wall but not for the objects that also fail for Gazebo. So the FBX collada exporter (used for Atlas) and OpenCOLLADA exporter (used for polaris) seem to be doing something different than Blender's and SketchUp's exporters that rviz is able to handle but other programs including gazebo aren't.

content.raw:
Regarding @nkoenig's question about ogre.log:

I don't get any errors related to Atlas textures, but depending on the file path i use for the texture in the NIST wall I either get an error or a success message about loading the texture. In either case it shows up in Gazebo however (even when ogre.log shows an error about not being able to load the texture):

- using ../materials/textures/plywood256x256.jpg for the collada texture tag (the file printed in the error message does exist):

        01:39:00: OGRE EXCEPTION(6:FileNotFoundException): Cannot locate resource /home/thomas/gazebo_models/nist_maze_wall_120/meshes/../materials/textures/plywood256x256.jpg in resource group General or any other group. in ResourceGroupManager::openResource at /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/src/OgreResourceGroupManager.cpp (line 753)
        01:39:00: Error loading texture /home/thomas/gazebo_models/nist_maze_wall_120/meshes/../materials/textures/plywood256x256.jpg. Texture layer will be blank. Loading the texture failed with the following exception: OGRE EXCEPTION(6:FileNotFoundException): Cannot locate resource /home/thomas/gazebo_models/nist_maze_wall_120/meshes/../materials/textures/plywood256x256.jpg in resource group General or any other group. in ResourceGroupManager::openResource at /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/src/OgreResourceGroupManager.cpp (line 753)

- using just plywood256x256.jpg for collada's texture tag:

         01:43:26: Texture: /home/thomas/gazebo_models/nist_maze_wall_120/meshes/../materials/textures/plywood256x256.jpg: Loading 1 faces(PF_R8G8B8,256x256x1) with 5 generated mipmaps from Image. Internal format is PF_X8R8G8B8,256x256x1.
